Wrappers

based on https://github.com/lucidrains/all-normalization-transformer/blob/master/all_normalization_transformer/all_normalization_transformer.py

{% raw %}

class Residual[source]

Residual(sublayer) :: Module

Add skip-connection: out = x + sublayer(x)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class PostNorm[source]

PostNorm(dim, sublayer) :: Module

Adds LayerNorm after sublayer

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class PreNorm[source]

PreNorm(dim, sublayer) :: Module

Adds LayerNorm before sublayer

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Pointwise FeedForward

{% raw %}

class FeedForward[source]

FeedForward(dim, d_ff=None, dropout=0.0) :: Module

Simple positional feed-forward module with GELU activation function. If d_ff is None defaults to 4*d_model

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
bs = 4
sl = 128
d = 64
x = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
ff  = Residual(PreNorm(d, FeedForward(d)))
out = ff(x)
assert (bs, sl, d) == out.size()
out.shape

torch.Size([4, 128, 64])
{% endraw %}

Attention

{% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class Attention[source]

Attention(d_model:int, n_heads:int=8, causal:bool=False, mask:Tensor=None, dropout:float=0.1, out_dropout:float=None, bias:bool=False, store_attention:bool=False) :: Module

Standard attention module using scaled dot-product attention

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class AdditiveAttention[source]

AdditiveAttention(dim, n_heads=8, causal=False, mask=None, dropout=0.1, bias=True) :: Module

Additive attention combining self and cross attention

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class AttnInProj[source]

AttnInProj(d_model:int, bias:bool=False) :: Module

Computes q, k, v from input x and [optional] context

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
bs = 4
sl = 128
d = 64
x = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
context = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
proj = AttnInProj(d)
q1, k1, v1 = proj(x)
assert (bs, sl, d) == q1.size() == k1.size() == v1.size()
q1.shape, k1.shape, v1.shape

(torch.Size([4, 128, 64]), torch.Size([4, 128, 64]), torch.Size([4, 128, 64]))
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
q2, k2, v2 = proj(x, context)
assert (bs, sl, d) == q2.size()
assert k2.size() == v2.size() == context.size()
assert (q1==q2).all()
assert not (k1==k2).all()
q2.shape, k2.shape, v2.shape

(torch.Size([4, 128, 64]), torch.Size([4, 128, 64]), torch.Size([4, 128, 64]))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class ScaledDotProdAttention[source]

ScaledDotProdAttention(d_model, n_heads, causal=False, dropout=0.0, store_attention:bool=False) :: Module

Same as nn.Module, but no need for subclasses to call super().__init__

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Scaled dot-product attention is calculated as:

{% raw %} $$\textbf {Attention}(Q,K,V) = \textbf {softmax}({QK^T\over\sqrt d_k})V $$ {% endraw %}

{% raw %} 
q = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
k = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
v = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
attn_func = ScaledDotProdAttention(d, 4)
out = attn_func(q, k, v)
out.shape

torch.Size([4, 128, 64])
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class Attention[source]

Attention(d_model:int, n_heads:int=8, causal:bool=False, mask:Tensor=None, dropout:float=0.1, out_dropout:float=None, bias:bool=False, store_attention:bool=False) :: Module

Standard attention module using scaled dot-product attention

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
x = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
attn  = Residual(PreNorm(d, Attention(d)))
out = attn(x)
out.shape

torch.Size([4, 128, 64])
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
x = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
context = torch.randn(bs, sl-20, d)
attn  = Residual(PreNorm(d, Attention(d)))

out = attn(x, context)
out.shape

torch.Size([4, 128, 64])
{% endraw %}

Transformer blocks

Encoder

{% raw %}

class TransformerEncoderBlock[source]

TransformerEncoderBlock(dim, n_heads=8, causal=False, mask=None, attn_dropout=0.1, attn_bias=True, ff_dropout=0.1, d_ff=None, prenorm=False) :: Module

Bacis transformer encoder block. Consists of multi-head attention and positional feedforward layers

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
x = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
m = TransformerEncoderBlock(d)
out = m(x)
out.shape

torch.Size([4, 128, 64])
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class TransformerEncoder[source]

TransformerEncoder(dim, depth=6, n_heads=8, causal=False, d_ff=None, attn_dropout=0.1, attn_bias=True, ff_dropout=0.1, prenorm=False, final_norm=None) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
x = torch.randn(bs, sl, d)
m = TransformerEncoder(d)
out = m(x)
out.shape

torch.Size([4, 128, 64])
{% endraw %}

Decoder

class TransformerDecoderBlock[source]

TransformerDecoderBlock(dim, n_heads=8, mask=None, d_ff=None, attn_dropout=0.1, ff_dropout=0.1, attn_bias=True, prenorm=False) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class TransformerDecoder[source]

TransformerDecoder(dim, depth=6, n_heads=8, d_ff=None, attn_dropout=0.1, ff_dropout=0.1, prenorm=False, comb_attn=False, attn_bias=True, final_norm=None) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

class AbsolutePositionalEmbedding[source]

AbsolutePositionalEmbedding(dim, max_seq_len) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class FixedPositionalEmbedding[source]

FixedPositionalEmbedding(dim) :: Module

Base class for all neural network modules.

Your models should also subclass this class.

Modules can also contain other Modules, allowing to nest them in a tree structure. You can assign the submodules as regular attributes::

import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F

class Model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(Model, self).__init__()
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(1, 20, 5)
        self.conv2 = nn.Conv2d(20, 20, 5)

    def forward(self, x):
        x = F.relu(self.conv1(x))
        return F.relu(self.conv2(x))

Submodules assigned in this way will be registered, and will have their parameters converted too when you call :meth:to, etc.

:ivar training: Boolean represents whether this module is in training or evaluation mode. :vartype training: bool

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class TransformerEmbedding[source]

TransformerEmbedding(emb_sz, dim, max_seq_len=512, dropout=0.0, pos_enc='absolute', axial_shape=None, axial_emb_dims=None) :: Module

Combines token embedings with positional encodings pos_enc: str from {'absolute', 'fixed', 'axial'}

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
vocab_sz = 256
bs = 4
sl = 128
d = 64
x = torch.randint(vocab_sz, (bs, sl))
emb = TransformerEmbedding(vocab_sz, d)
out = emb(x)
assert (bs, sl, d) == out.size()
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
vocab_sz = 256
bs = 4
sl = 128
d = 64
x = torch.randint(vocab_sz, (bs, sl))
emb = TransformerEmbedding(vocab_sz, d, pos_enc='fixed')
out = emb(x)
assert (bs, sl, d) == out.size()
{% endraw %}
